awd_titl_txt: Rigidity, Volume, and Combinatorics in Hyperbolic Geometry
awd_abstract_narration:
For much of the twentieth century, the challenge to describe the shape of three dimensional spaces was viewed as an algebraic problem: indeed it is through algebra that we first distinguish the (topological) structure of a sphere from that of a doughnut. Work of William Thurston brought the geometry of such spaces more clearly into view as a central feature to explore. The triumph of this approach was Perelman's proof of Thurston's geometrization conjecture, that each three-dimensional manifold could be naturally broken up into pieces, each with a uniform geometry. The study of these geometries is frequently reduced, via a notion of rigidity, to considering simple combinatorial structures arising from loops on surfaces. The proposed research will explore how these structures predict volume, diameter, length and other aspects of the geometry, relating to notions from quantum physics.

A longstanding connection between volume of hyperbolic three-manifolds and Weil-Petersson distance relied on a combinatorial comparison via the pants graph which organizes maximal multicurves on a surface, yet other connections were known to arise from work of Witten via renormalized volume. Recent work of Schlenker made this connection explicit in the context of quasi-Fuchsian manifolds, and PI's proposed work will develop this idea further to explicitly relate fibered 3-manifolds and translation distiance. More generally, a primary project in the proposed research is to solidify and extend the connection between combinatorics and geometry in closed manifolds, and to continue to investigate the structure of deformation spaces of Kleinian groups with these tools. As an example of the power of these techniques, bi-Lipschitz models for 'random' Heegaard splittings provide a full solution (with Rivin and Souto) to the conjecture of Dunfield and Thurston that random Heegaard splittings are almost surely hyperbolic and their volume grows linearly. Finally, the PI will pursue projects with Minsky, and with Modami, Leininger and Rafi on the role of combinatorics in the geometry of geodesics in the Weil-Petersson metric, investigating disparities between Teichmuller and Weil-Petersson geodesics in terms of unique ergodicity.

por.por_cntn:
The study of hyperbolic geometry, the non-euclidean geometry most famously used to understand the physical notion of relativity in Einstein's work, describes a range of mathematical phenomena in dimensions two and three, phenomena that can be described to the public. A central idea that does not require understanding of Einstein's theories can be more readily described: if we allow space to expand as we move away from a given point, tree-like structures (communication and social networks, phylogenetics, or neural architectures) are better accommodated by this non-euclidean, expanding geometry. 

The work in this project has sought to understand the way these non-euclidean geometries can vary or change over time as configurations evolve. One can think of this evolution as a kind of 'flow', where geometry changes continuously to accommodate evolving constraints. 

Remarkably, such evolutions can frequently be described by simple pieces of data, like a combination of numbers or shapes that are simple to describe. Our work has sought to understand how the geometric evolutions we seek to understand are determined by these data. In some sense, we want to know not only the destination, but the process and route we take to get there. 

And as we have investigated this process, we have learned new things about the behavior of these hyperbolic geometries along the way. By questioning how these evolutions occur, new phenomena have been uncovered that challenge the very basics of how we think about the geometric spaces involved. 

Indeed we come full circle to physics, where the notion of renormalized volume (a way physicists like to pretend that infinite volume spaces actually have finite volume!) behaves kind of like water flowing downhill: as we follow the 'gradient' or the direction of fastest water-flow, we are led to new features of the geometries involved. These features have led to new conjectures and new approaches to old conjectures in mathematics. 

Ultimately, we are pushing the frontier of what is known by mathematicians and physicists alike, about the real universe and the imagined one that emerges when we build a model for the universe. We cannot provide a concrete time horizon for when we will come to the full understanding and realization of the truths that underlie our work, but we continue to discover and evolve our state of knowledge by following our curiosity and remaining on vigilant watch for ways  that new knowledge we discover along the way can help to understand the current and pressing problems that confront society and the world around us.
